docs.title: Coordination is hard when people must commit to choices.
docs.text:
• Government leadership plays a central role
  • Many individuals/families commit to their own choices
  • Massive amount occurring in the informal domain

Not only communicating data:

  • Inform people, learn from people, coordinate decisions

We have over a decade of tools and platforms to support this governance, information exchange, and coordinated decision making

Early US work:

  • Drought information, water markets, and farm planting choices
  • Coordinating seed planting in Arizona

This work was performed by the Wu Lab in the Department of Computer Science and the National Center for Disaster Preparedness in the Climate School, both at Columbia University. The US National Science Foundation funded much of the software infrastructure used.

docs.title: Your thoughts? Storm/Evacuation/Shelter?
docs.text:
• We are building a public domain platform for disaster experts to set up their own games.
  • We have been thinking about disaster games in the US and need your thoughts.
  • Interface, usefulness, appropriate applications, accuracy access to all voices, bias, equity, privacy?...
  • I have used the design interface put together a quick illustration of what the first few steps of a hypothetical game might be to get the discussion going

docs.title: What game would you make?
docs.text:
• What would the game be about?
  • What is an example question?
  • Sending information vs gathering information from people?
  • How realistic vs. hypothetical?
  • Fun or “exercise” (how much to frame as a game)?
  • Who is your target audience, for example, players?
  • Potential concerns?
  • What strategies would you use to make sure different voices are represented?
  • What strategies would you use to filter people playing for fun vs those sharing real knowledge? Other thoughts? Existing Simulations, Tabletops that might connect?

docs.title: Gamification for trust building, teaching, data gathering, and coordinated decision-making?
docs.text:
• Defined as the use of game design elements in non-game contexts—in agriculture through websites, apps, and SMS

  • More fun, quicker, and more motivating but likely biased and less accurate, and may only reach a subgroup

    • Can utilize intrinsic (e.g., fun) or extrinsic (e.g., prize) motivation
    • At the intersection of serious games, persuasive technology, and personal informatics
    • Games can educate, incentivize information reporting, and help communities understand each other.
    • They can provide a safe space to work through sensitive issues in a “hypothetical” case
  • Trying to turn one-way SMS alert blasts into two-way communication and sustained learning

Games 2020, 11(4), 47; https://doi.org/10.3390/g11040047

docs.title: IKON Game: Colombia Lessons
docs.text:
• Prize given to best scoring.
  • 146 played, and they invited others
  • Average player played 200 rounds
  • Winner, 16-year-old with her grandmother.
  • Women were more accurate than men
  • Prizes
    • Didn’t improve reporting quality
    • Did increase participation
  • Most people played for fun, not accuracy
  • Everyone might learn…but the information-gathering goal is to identify super trainers, who are about 20% of players who are very accurate--use their responses, understand biases

docs.title: Idea: Make the game configurable by the Emergency or Disaster Manager.
This is particularly challenging in disasters
docs.text:
• Community interaction revealing to everyone

  • Caribbean workshop on events, rainfall, and forecasts

    • Worst storms were the ones that hit on holidays, not necessarily the strongest storms
    • Focus group holiday outcome was verified with research
    • Massive implications for disaster preparedness and planning
  • But we can only do so many focus groups…
  • So, we spent a lot of time and money on technology to help automate
  • Decades of work in Africa, Asia, the Caribbean, and Latin America have yielded new approaches, tools
    • Quantitative hybrid in-person/computerized focus groups became possible at large-scale (many thousands of meetings, millions of people served)
